questions.question_text: Which three conditions are required for two FortiGate devices to form an OSPF adjacency? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
A. OSPF is only on local interfaces.
B. net-device creates separate interfaces for each dial-up, i.e. tunnel_0, tunnel_1 - p311 of Study Guide
C. what?
D. add-route disabled means static routes are not added and require dynamic routing protocol. - p313 of Study Guide.

Selected Answer: BD
B and D are correct

choices.D: add-route is disabled in the tunnel IPSec phase 1 configuration.
choices.A: OSPF is configured to run over IPSec.
choices.B: net-device is enabled in the tunnel IPSec phase 1 configuration.

choices.A: You must configure it globally only.
choices.D: It works for OSPF and BGP.
choices.C: It can support neighbors only over the next hop in BGP.
choices.B: You can disable it at the protocol level.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
B and D are correct

questions.question_text:
You want to configure faster failure detection for BGP.

Which parameter should you enable on both connected FortiGate devices?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct
Study Guide 7.2 Page 202

Selected Answer: D
Study Guide Page 204

Selected Answer: D
p202 in Study Guide.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct.
- Mechanism detecting a one way device failure.
- Used for faster convergence of routing protocols.
- Independent interface media, routing, or data protocol.
- Draft RFCs with multiple encapsulation types.
- FortiGate uses unicast packet, UDP port 3784 (not routable)
- BFD vs "Fortinet Dead Gateway Detection" (DGD)
-Fast convergence (<1s)
-Devices must be on the same subnet
-Interoperable support of BFD required between vendors
-Designed for OSPF and BGP

https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Technical-Tip-FortiGate-BFD-implementation-and-examples/ta-p/190484
